value.text: I've removed the Bluesky data from the repo. While I wanted to support tool development for the platform, I recognize this approach violated principles of transparency and consent in data collection. I apologize for this mistake.

Delete your account

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: What do you mean when you say "Ive removed this data for now"?

It has been permanently deleted. The ‚Äòfor now‚Äô is just a reference to the fact that we should have an open discussion about how to obtain consent. 

Someone will create this dataset, we‚Äôd rather it was done in a way that is respectful of users wishes. That seems to be what everyone wants too.

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: Your org sucks. Your industry (look at the likes on these posts) sucks.

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: Getting back to this for a moment, Daniel uses the phrase "deleted for now" twice more in the repo. This is for anyone reading this later. Why he uses that specofic phrase not just here, but also more than once in the repo comment is beyond me if its as simple as "we want to keep the dialogue open"

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: Actually the for now language in the repo has been removed, in the last hour. Im glad to see that.

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: It was there, I wish Id screenshot it.

I feel like you are attributing malice where there is none. It seems pretty clear to me that the implication is that when we have figured out how to let users consent, a new dataset can be created. The bluesky team are also interested in figuring this out.

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: Im not attributing malice. Im  incredulous. The language was there an hour ago. As we spoke in another thread, Daniel respinded to multiple people while the set was up, but only people who spoke positively of the scraped data. Around the time the set got pulled bsky issued a statement about scraping

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: I dont think, based on any of what i just stated, being suspicious is unfounded or unwarranted.

I mean it isn't a huge conspiracy. Daniel was excited by the possibilities, created dataset (because bluesky is open and easily accessible and daniel loves data). Wasn't thought through, mistake was corrected.

Hanlon's razor.

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: Well again, my point is/was to highlight the repeated use of the phrase "for now" both in this announcement and at least twice on the repo. And that language in the repo has since been removed and im glad to see that it was removed.
We were discussing this internally before the bluesky thread. Everything has just happened very quickly.

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: My wishes, many people's wishes, arguably most people's wishes, are that the LLMs being fed this data would simultaneously implode, permanently and irrevocably.

Understandable but unlikely. 

What we can do though is work towards a solution that ensures your data, and the data of anyone who agrees with you, does not get used to train AI. 

Closed companies will do what they do, we can‚Äôt affect that, but we can try to set some standards.
I love your implication that progress is simply inevitable, as if you yourself weren't one of the hands turning the crank that you could simply stop doing at literally any time.
anti-progress*

Movement in some direction is inevitable, it is less about preventing that (because we don‚Äôt think it is inherently ‚Äòbad‚Äô) and more course correction. 

We fundamentally disagree with the position that AI is all bad. So we see value in trying to make it work better for all.
Or, and hear me out, you could just do other things with your life instead of working on generative AI.
I mean, I don‚Äôt work on generative AI but ok.

AI is literally adding to the destruction of the planet every time someone uses this stupid toy to (very badly) pretend to do work they can't be bothered to do, or aren't qualified to do, and are prepared to steal other people's genuine hard work in order to fake it.
The default standard, when no standard is defined, is don't touch other people's data at all. If you don't ask first you are removing consent no matter how you spin it.
You don't actually have to build the Torment Nexus, and you certainly don't need to try and justify building the Torment Nexus just because someone else might do it later.
Yes.
I concur with this.
Also everyone involved should lose their jobs. At least.

Let me see if I understand. Your excuse is that you assumed someone was going to consentlessly scrape everyones shit for personal gain and the detriment of users and the planet, and then thought "well golly, we better get in there first!"
sir you posted on a public social media platform
Consent is freely implied in usage of an open protocol.
I don't remember checking the box ‚ÄúI wish my data was exported to the Hugging Face‚Äù when signing up for @bsky.app.
Prob gonna add it back in a week after this has all died down but just not post about it lmao

author.displayName: Did Old Hank Really Do It This a-Way?

record.text: Thats my concern. And props to pngwn here for trying to be in front of it and being a much better communicator on this than Daniel has. But im not convinced that this wont happen again, and i wish the entire AI bubble would hurry up and burst.
"For now"? Seriously?
I want to be able to consent to having my posting and commenting available for anyone to use. Please give me a way to do that -- or if there is a way, please publicize it better!

I respect people who don't want their writing and thoughts used for training. On the other hand this thread a good source of people who rudely express strong negative judgments with no explanation. I block those people. Keep BlueSky friendly (or at least civil)!
Respect
People don‚Äôt need to explain why they don‚Äôt want their identity fed into the plagiarism machine. This is a weird expectation.
Taking data without consent is significantly more more rude than saying some mean words.

record.text:
docs.bsky.app/docs/categor...

docs.bsky.app/docs/api/com...

Here's where you can find your posts:
bsky.social/xrpc/com.atp...

There are *pointers* to things you've replied to, but only your own posts are actually returned. (I really like the HTTP API.)

external.title: HTTP Reference | Bluesky
external.description: This section contains HTTP API reference docs for Bluesky and AT Protocol lexicons, presented in an OpenAPI format.

record.text: If you feel like being ultra cautious you could remove the reply fields entirely
You're a fucking weirdo for that.
I can create more data and give it to you if you pay me.
legally speaking, what does "for now" mean?
it means bluesky's lawyers sent him an email telling him this is super fucking illegal in the EU

I honestly don't know if it is because that's part of the protocol, to have everything ever posted be public and publicly available. Once there is public data, I don't know how you obtain consent so I don't think it's been clearly challenged in EU courts. The act of posting is givng consent in a way
By that logic, the act of sharing your works means you have no copyright?

That's not exactly the same. There's extremely clear rulings around that (though is legal precedent really something we can rely on anymore...üòì), there _aren't_ around this. I honestly think it was probably illegal but it's gray enough that it would probably require a ruling.

Reddit and their like have sold their content to be used by LLMs because they own it because it was created on their platform (per their terms of service). I truly don't know how you do that with a publicly available protocol ü§£ it's all gray areas ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

The EU writes better laws now than the US (I think it's Denmark that literally has someone attached to their congress that edits laws so they can be implemented unlike GDPR was written) but they still are pretty broad. I had multiple people asking for content on the EU AI Act for a reason üòÖ
GDPR does not care if it was public previously, Right To Be Forgotten means it must be deleteable.
It is deleteable in the app BTW so anyone using the app - the thing actually provided by the company - so anyone using that cannot access it through said app (or website)
As in, if the fundamental architecture means deletability is impossible, they have a much much much bigger problem, because GDPR says ‚Äúno, you move. Or be fined into the Sun.‚Äù

That's the company, not the protocol. I'm sorry but do you honestly think they didn't consult lawyers about this when they built the company? Like you have to delete the person's info at the company level but the protocol itself isn't tied to a company.

Honestly? It wouldn‚Äôt be the first time in my experience that either no lawyer was consulted, or only a lawyer who did not have the requisite expertise was consulted. But hey, I‚Äôm mostly going on year after year of GDPR trainings for tech companies that handle personal data.

author.displayName: Living for the spite of it all

record.text: If I‚Äôm in there, get me the fuck out - right now, asshole. No one asked for my permission nor do I give consent.
hi can you show me where you were granted a license to use my content for commercial purposes
can you show me where he‚Äôs using your content for commercial purposes
that a $4.5B company offers a freemium tier to its users does not make its use of pilfered content "non-commercial"
Just ignor fox guy. He is Ai troll from twitter with IQ of a toddler. He has been ridiculed that so much he had to escape here.

calling hugging face‚Äôs dataset archives a freemium tier of their paid offering is like calling google search a freemium tier of Google Cloud

they‚Äôre completely different services, this one being free and non-commercial
that's not how "commercial" and "noncommercial" works, muting you now because you're an ass
I mean Google Search is a commercial product just on its own.
I was responding to the ‚Äúfreemium tier‚Äù point if it were not obvious.
Calling your opinions shit is an insult to shit
this is correct
Wait is google search not a commercial product? That‚Äôs an insane stance to take

That wasn‚Äôt the stance. The stance was that it is not a freemium tier of Google Cloud, because it is different service.

In this case, the ‚Äúdifferent service‚Äù is not motivated by profit, so it‚Äôs noncommercial.
not seeing any commercial activity here
all of those things are potentially commercial applications but the commercial activity i'm talking about is making my content available to the users of their compute platform without my consent

they made it available to anyone on any compute platform. theirs does not get any special privileges in this regard. it‚Äôs the same thing universities, archive.org, etc., do. if you‚Äôve posted on twitter, odds are, archive.org did this to you already.
archive.org is not a commercial entity! hugging face is a commercial entity!
A commercial entity can do noncommercial things, as is the case here. I don‚Äôt get what‚Äôs so hard to understand about that.
is anarchism about licenses now

They don't seem mutually exclusive.

Anarchism is based on cooperation without hierarchy or coercion. A license is a way to agree on cooperation terms.

Someone using your stuff without any agreement at the very least shows they're being a dick.

It only breaks down if the anarchist calls the cops.
Public facing soc-network website. How the fuck do you use a site and not think your public presence shouldn't meld with the noosphere?

I'm not arguing the expectations of public content, much less of that on a social network - that's a separate discussion and, given it's an issue of opinion, likely one not worth having.

I'm stating that anarchism is not incompatible with software or content licenses, only coercive enforcement is.

Hi, you‚Äôre using people‚Äôs content - which they own - without consent, and in violation of Bluesky‚Äôs ToS.

You need to make an opt-out or prepare to be sued.

While they may have removed the data due to community pushback, I maintain that its collection and publication as a set violated several aspects of BlueSky's ToS. This includes the right to know when your data is being used by third parties, and the right to opt-out of certain data processing.
They should be banned outright for the ToS violation, and frankly BlueSky should require an opt-in model b/c your content can‚Äôt be unbaked from an LLM.
This is horrible. Don't do this.

Regading the Terms of Bluesky, section 2D, you have no right, to use any of my content. If your database contains any content or Data from the user @romanvilgut.eu Based on international copyright law and the GDPR I therefore command you to delete from your database.

images.alt:
2B.
Your Responsibility for User Content. You, not Bluesky, are solely responsible for all of your User Content. Bluesky does not control others‚Äô use of your content

record.text:
That's not what 2D says, Roman. 2D actually says that you are granting Bluesky the none exclusive right to do with your data whatever they like to do, including passing it on to third parties "to improve their services".

they also explicitely don't control what others do with your content (2B)

images.alt:

record.text:
Yes, I am allowing Bluesky to do so. But not huggingface. But they deleted the data anyway.

Btw: That is reason, why I want to move my data away from bluesky. The AT-Protocol makes this very hard, with ActivityPub I can at least choose the server, I like

Which is entirely in line with and required by how the underlying technology was designed. You know, that whole decentralization thing.

Your GDPR claim is likely valid, because Hugging Face didn't anonymize the data. That you need direct towards HF. Copyright claim may also be valid, depending on
jurisdiction (probably not in the US due to fair use).
That‚Äôs the thing about requests, they‚Äôre only enforceable if there‚Äôs an agreed jurisdiction. So it‚Äôs really asking for a favor.
Please provide detailed instructions on how to opt my data out of this dataset. GTFOH with this.

record.text: Ah, okay.  I ain't a law person, as you can tell.
since when were bluesky‚Äôs policies the law?
Its important to me that you understand companies are allowed to set rules on their websites

ok but since when was breaking a rule illegal (and just so we are clear, it is important to me that you understand that the rules do not forbid this in any way, and that, in fact, the website was designed to facilitate these behaviors via atproto)
"Since when was breaking a rule illegal" okay champ, have a good one.
Rules aren‚Äôt laws. Private companies cannot make laws.

"illegal" means "breaking the law" not "breaking a rule". Breaking a rule carries social consequences, breaking a law carries legal consequences. There's a massive difference that should never be blended together.
"When i grow up, i want to argue semantics of language online with strangers" - you, aged 7
Wow, buddy, that was super cool! You totally got em! Good for you! Time for bed now!
I like the sort of brain that cant understand the nuances of language and then responds with something like this.
bluesky rules do not carry force of law lol
Why is it always the furry accounts
Don't lump me in with him! I don't argue in bad faith with strawman arguments

Not a furry, so let me jump in: they're quite correct. Terms of service are not legally binding, they constrain the licence of intellectual property - the enforcement of which is provided for by civil law (DCMA notwithstanding).

Disclaimer: not remotely defending the dataset, just clarifying.

Whoa dude, this is really out of pocket considering the amount of furries in the comments that are clearly against this.   
Don‚Äôt throw the rest of us under the bus to jab at some asshole please and thank you.
Eh, it's either that or they're armchair communists so I'm pretty much spent on that

???

I am aware of like maybe 3 other furries with positive opinions of AI-related companies and every single other furry seems to hate them all.
No I mean they're all stupid
You aren't very smart are you?
A contract, by definition, carries the force of law.
If that's true then why have rules? You literally have to agree to these when you sign up.

So you can ban people who violate them? When Congress makes something illegal in a law, they specify what the punishment will be for breaking the law. What does the Bluesky TOS say the punishment is for scraping the firehose?

Yes they do! In the US not complying with the terms of service of a computer service is a violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, in the UK it's a violation of the Computer Misuse Act, need I go on? Nearly every nation has laws along these lines.

That is extremely oversimplified. There are terms of service which can be enforced legally in certain circumstances (laid out in those legislations). But imagine a world where a company makes up arbitrary rules that they can sue you for when breaking them. That would be terrible.

These are criminal laws and enforced by law enforcement. Bluesky cam enforce its terms through the court (separately to these laws) but, in the UK at least, the terms can't be "unfair" (which "arbitrary" terms probably would be, but a prohibition on scraping is not).

They *can* sue you for breaking arbitrary rules! That's the whole purpose of a terms of service! And breaking some of those rules CAN supplementally be a criminal act.

What do you think the enforcement mechanism for terms-of-service compliance is? It's not merely termination of service.
The bluesky rules are dictated by actual laws and regulations in each country and they have to be compliant. So yeah, indirectly, it is the force of law.
by creating your account, you agreed to tos, a legally-binding contractual agreement. breaking that contractual agreement is a violation of the law by definition of what a contract is.
Ok. What does the law say is the penalty for breaching the contract? And what does the contract say about scraping the firehose?

idk, read the policy. i really don't care enough to look. this being against the rules isnt the problem to me, but if it is in fact against the rules then yes it's illegal

as for the punishment, that'd be a court's decision‚Äîtho bsky'd probably handle it themselves with a ban before it came to that

i highly doubt this would turn into any kind of lawsuit that would need to be settled in court so it really doesn't matter too much that this is illegal. also this is just talking about the US. if legality is your concern, other countries ofc will have different laws & you'd need to look into that
Foxie is right, Bluesky's privacy policy literally says that profile and posts are public. It is literally the first section there.
hi fox! those who didn‚Äôt attend carnegie mellon learned about topics like ethics and consent, perhaps something to look into
are you okay in the head?
Since the law recognizes legal contracts freely entered into between two parties. The contract quite literally has the force of law behind it and its terms can be enforced in a civil court.
But I know AI cultists like you don‚Äôt understand that the law applies to you. You‚Äôll still be in court one day wondering why you‚Äôre even there.

The law is "copyright" which says that unless I give someone explicit permission to do something with my "creative works" (which includes skeets), they aren't allowed to do anything.

BlueSky ToS say which rights I granted to them. "Share freely with AI training sets" is not among that list.

You give them permission to share your posts, and Huggingface has permission to scrape them (legally), and, so long as their lawyers can show it‚Äôs fair use, distribute those posts accordingly.

Archive.org is doing fine, so I suspect  their‚Äôs Huggingface‚Äôs lawyers know it‚Äôs fair use.

You _really_ need to talk to a copyright lawyer about what the fair use doctrine does and doesn't allow before you keep saying more idiotic things. At least read the wikipedia page: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_use

record.text: P.S. Distributing the model is not distributing the verbatim posts. That's what makes it different from archive.org ‚Ä¶¬†and what makes the generation of that model a violation of my copyright (and of BlueSky's ToS).

record.text: They‚Äôre not distributing a model. They‚Äôre distributing a firehose archive. archive.org does the same thing. This is where you can follow archiveteam‚Äôs creation of a much larger version of what Hugging Face published: archive.org/details/arch...

external.title: Internet Archive: Digital Library of Free & Borrowable Texts, Movies, Music & Wayback Machine

record.text:
Ok, I see your point here. So it's more about the stupidity of sharing the data (likely still in violation of bsky ToS) on a site dedicated to using data to do things explicitly disallowed by the license.

Sort of like slapping "not for human consumption" on a jug of chocolate flavored raw milk.

Hugging Face does a lot. They run a free service to host datasets for researchers. Twitter firehose data was *the* dataset for hate speech and misinformation research, and Elon famously killed it. Hugging Face tried to bring it back, explicitly restricting use in their license to what was allowed by
For example, this is 10 GB: archive.org/details/arch... and just a small proportion of what archive.org distributes from Bluesky scraping.
